body.name: The People’s Princess: The brand new historical novel based on the gripping true stories of two British princesses who defied the monarchy and were loved by the people

productInformation.name: Best Sellers Rank

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 29, 2022
reviews.reviewText: A fictionalized biography of the late Princess Diana which takes the reader through her engagement to Prince Charles up the wedding day, intertwined with a fictionalized biography of Princess Charlotte, “the queen who never was”, granddaughter of George III. It’s interesting to read the stories of the two young women who may well have been quite similar in temperament, and to speculate how things just might have turned out a little differently in each case…if Charlotte had lived, or perhaps if there hadn’t been a Camilla.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 19, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Two tragic princesses
reviews.reviewText: This book is unusual because it juxtaposes the stories of two British princesses who died young: Diana, Princess of Wales, and Princess Charlotte, the heir to the throne in the early 1800s. The chapters go back and forth between the two women -- Diana on the eve of her wedding to Charles, and Charlotte as a young woman resisting marriage to a foreign prince she doesn't like. Despite the ultimately sad subject matter, I found both of the stories interesting, and the writing flows well.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 24, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars 2 princess's with tragic lives
reviews.reviewText: I did not realize there was a Princess Charlotte in England's history that had a difficult life very similar to Princess Diana. They both died far too young. Like so many people I am still very fascinated with Diana's life after her death. Very interesting story.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 19, 2022
reviews.reviewText: When I saw there was a novel featuring Princess Diana, I was so excited! However, it didn't take long to realize the title is a bit misleading. The book was more about Princess Charlotte than Diana. I did enjoy the connection and similarities between the two. It was also interesting reading about a royal family member I knew nothing about. In that respect I enjoyed it. It's just that the title had me thinking we'd see Diana later in life (or at least more about her in general). My other quip is that writing style felt more geared toward a YA audience than an adult, which is fine but that's personally something I like to be prepared for ahead of time.I ended up enjoying Charlotte's side of the story more. My heart breaks for her, but I'm glad here her life was able to provide consolation to a young and anxious Diana as she set forth to her own life of royalty. The dynamic was very touching. I also liked the frankness of Diana's struggles and her confrontations with Charles. Mentions of Camilla were difficult, but I was glad the book ended on a positive note. Despite it not being what I expected, it was a nice read and it reawakened my interest in Princess Diana after several years.Thank you to Harper Collins and NetGalley for sending me a free copy. I am leaving this review voluntarily and I have since purchased the book for myself on Kindle.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 21, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Parallel tracks through History
reviews.reviewText: This historical fiction follows two Princesses of Wales from two different centuries who shared remarkably similar personalities. The way the author combines their histories gives the reader an inside look at palace life with its privileges and demands. The reader cannot help but wonder what if things had turned out differently. An absorbing read.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 20, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Seeing the Royalty
reviews.reviewText: I have not been one to read about England’s royalty so this was a different kind of read for me and I really enjoyed it. It was interesting to read of Charlotte’s life as compared to Diana’s. I often wondered about some of the details.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 25, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Charlotte was a star
reviews.reviewText: I know that this is called Historical Fiction but, this story about Charlotte was news to me. I really enjoyed thinking that it was about her live.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 11, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I bought this to listen to at night when I go to sleep it is a very interesting aspect on the princess.

reviews.reviewTitle: A used book which was in perfect condition.
reviews.reviewText: This book is a great read especially if you read or saw the Crown.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on March 31, 2022
reviews.reviewText: ‘The People’s Princess’ by Flora Harding explores through historical fiction the lives of two Princesses of Wales; one born to the royal title and the other born into the British aristocracy and married into royalty.I combined reading with its unabridged audiobook edition, narrated by Julie Teal.Buckingham Palace, 1981. Lady Diana Spencer has recently become engaged to Prince Charles. It may have seemed a dream come true but now she’s finding herself bored and alone. Courtiers seek to instruct her on royal protocol but the soon-to-be Princess of Wales finds it all very stuffy and rebels. Yet she finds the centuries of tradition too intractable and is increasingly unhappy.When she comes across a portrait of Princess Charlotte of Wales, the granddaughter of George III and the only child of the Prince Regent, she finds herself drawn to the tragic princess. She is put in touch with Amelia Bell, who is working with the royal archives at Windsor Castle. Amelia lends Diana a transcript of Charlotte’s personal diary.From here the novel moves between Lady Diana as she prepares for her wedding and Charlotte’s diary from 1813 to her death in 1817. As Diana reads the diary, she sees many parallels with her own life and future as Princess of Wales. …I had mixed feelings about this novel as while I understand that the 1981 sections were based on accounts that Diana provided to friends and biographers, she comes across as immature and needy. Perhaps those who adore her might have sympathy but for myself it just further highlighted how unsuited she and Charles were even at this early stage. They really had so little common ground.Perhaps this was Harding’s intention though I also found the Diana chapters rather repetitive and felt that the chapters focusing on Princess Charlotte were more interesting; especially as I knew little about her life, including her death at such a young age.With respect to the audiobook, Julie Teal has narrated a wide range of audiobooks. Her voice is crystal clear and quite posh, perfect for the royal subject matter.In her Acknowledgements Flora Harding gives details of the sources she utilised for both timelines and stressed that as a novelist she has made her own interpretations of source material.Overall, while I found the Princess Charlotte chapters of more interest than the Lady Diana chapters I can appreciate the appeal of a novel that offers via historical fiction glimpses into these privileged lives.3.5 stars rounded up to 4.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 19, 2022
reviews.reviewText: Sorry, but after expecting a good read I found myself skipping the many chapters on the other princess, and what was written about Diana which had fewer chapters was like reading old news.
